user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_unique_dyn_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_unique_dyn_response (void *cls,
                            struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            const char *url,
                            const char *method,
                            const char *version,
                            const char *upload_data,
                            size_t *upload_data_size,
                            void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (body_dyn_size,
                                              body_dyn);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (body_dyn_size,
                                       (void *) body_dyn,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, r);
  MHD_destroy_response (r);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (body_dyn_size,
                                              body_dyn);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (body_dyn_size,
                                       (void *) body_dyn,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */

if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */
explanation: I selected fragments that can produce code that is never executed without further inspection: the first-call branch that returns immediately (may make later code unreachable for that call), the method-check that returns early for unsupported methods, and the conditional compilation pair (only one branch will be compiled in any build, making the other branch unreachable in that build). Other parts of the function were not selected because they are standard, reachable elements in normal control flow: variable declarations and initializations (static int marker, r, ret), the (void) casts to mark unused parameters, the calls to MHD_queue_response / MHD_destroy_response and the final return are reachable whenever the function proceeds past the early returns and are not intrinsically unreachable. No other unconditional statements remain in the source that cannot be executed under any feasible compilation or runtime condition, so they do not need investigation for unreachable-code concerns.
